EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Otay Water District - Ralph W. Chapman Water Recyling Facility is a responding facility. The facility will respond to and assist local first responders for all releases related to chlorine. This plan includes:
Emergency Alarm Procedures
Notification Procedures
Evacuation Procedures
Procedures in Response to Chlorine Release
Applicable Training and Responsibilities Associated with ICS
Emergency Aid Procedures 
Safety and Health Considerations

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The April 2023 PHA has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 2023 PHA Report. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by October 12, 2025. The facility has also conducted a Seismic Assessment on April 17, 2023, to test for facility integrity of external events. The results of the Seismic Assessment were documented in a formal report to attest the integrity of the facility.

ugh the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community, the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety systems to make the worst case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the facility and facility personnel that make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event. In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release:

There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place without exposing anyone to the chlorine.
The system is monitored by the SCADA system that would assist in preventing a deviation resulting in a release.
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by personnel, as necessary.
The system has chlorine sensors that automatically notify on the SCADA system and activate various alarms and shutdowns.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Otay Water District - Ralph W. Chapman Water Recycling Facility has had no CalARP-applicable incidents associated with the chlorine injection system in the past five (5) years.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

The Otay Water District - Ralph W. Chapman Water Recyling Facility has a long-standing commitment to its workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the chlorine injection system. The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Otay Water District - Ralph W. Chapman Water Recyling Facility treats and processes water for consumer use. The facility utilizes a Chlorine Injection System to sanitize the untreated water within the system. The facility has a max intended inventory of 10,000 pounds of chlorine within five (5) 1-ton chlorine cylinders (10,000 pounds).

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario
Per the CalARP Regulations one worst case analysis has been defined for the chlorine system.  RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment in the Compliance Workbook.  This worst-case release scenario is highly unlikely should a worst-case release occur, the sudden rupture and flashing would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly.

Alternative Release Scenario
The meteorological conditions specified by regulation for alternative release scenarios were used. RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The downwind distance for the alternative release scenario is significantly less than that for the worst-case scenarios.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.
